text: I wrote the storage migration stuffs today, it's pretty straight forward

The migration has a few parts and I just need to do it carefully, so moving the actual store files, then having users re-connect the repos, then adding the containers to the collections programatically

the one concern I have is that the actual hub is moving to a much smaller instance (half the size) and this is because I need to be more aware of costs, and the (rather costly build queue) I refactored so it's not needed
I really need more testers but I doubt it will happen, so I'll just release what we have, and then when people hit bugs they can file issues
I ran really fast so the adrenaline is still there, and I'm seeing all the work pay off for singularity hub (it's like, a thing) and I feel happy :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.title: Filesystem mounts in user namespaces
attachments.text: User namespaces are a sandbox within which an otherwise unprivileged user can appear to be root. Given a kernel with user namespaces enabled, any user can create such a namespace and, while they are running within it, do anything that root is allowed to do. The intent is that system administrators can allow the creation of these namespaces by unprivileged users, secure in the knowledge that any actions carried out within them will, in the context of the wider system, be constrained by the user's global credentials. There are some limits to what can be done within user namespaces though, with the mounting of filesystems being near the top of the list. A recent attempt to ease that limitation shows just how hard the problem is to solve.
attachments.fallback: Filesystem mounts in user namespaces

oh let me take a look
if you think there is a bug with the way we call it you need to test using the singularity client
test_docker_api.py explicitly sets old_version=True when calling get_manifest on <http://gcr.io/tensorflow/tensorflow|gcr.io/tensorflow/tensorflow>, so that makes it do Accept: application/json

sorry I don't think you saw what I said - if you look at the calls above, we are adding that header, it's essential to get it working. The problem is more likely to do with connectivity / connections. The latest media type is going to change pretty infrequently

I am having more success if I add —header 'Accept: application/vnd.docker.distribution.manifest.v2+json'.  So maybe the problem is that the definition of "latest" keeps changing, and there's a race condition where you get the list and meanwhile the definition of 'latest' changes and the media type no longer matches

so when you want to get layers, or a manifest, you also have to typically send a request for a token, parse the Authenticate heade they send back to get the scope, etc, then make the request, get the token, and add it to the request header

Ubuntu is not intentionally started in a docker container, but the two centos jobs are. Ahh, anther good find
They do not limit the total build, it's each individual job that they limit <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32128422/travis-ci-how-is-time-limit-counted-for-builds-sum-of-all-jobs-or-time-of-lo>

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Are_You_There_God%3F_It%27s_Me,_Margaret.>

attachments.title: Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret.
attachments.text: Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret is a 1970 book by Judy Blume, typically categorized as a young adult novel, about a sixth-grade girl who has grown up without a religious affiliation, due to her parents' interfaith marriage. The novel explores her quest for a single religion. Margaret also confronts typical issues faced by pre-teen girls going through puberty, such as buying her first bra, having her first period, and feeling attracted to certain boys. The novel has been frequently challenged since the 1980s due to its frank discussions of sexual and religious topics.
attachments.fallback: wikipedia: Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret.
